searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Add callback function when CoDrone battery percentage is lower than 50%  Syntax‚Äã  onLowBattery(function)  Parameters‚Äã  function: a callback function when battery is lower than 50%  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  //Arduino code //Not supported

searchDocs.title: getAccelerometer()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This function gets the accelerometer sensor data, which returns x, y, and z. It outputs as a struct in Arduino.  Syntax‚Äã  getAccelerometer()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  struct acceldata: Returns a struct with acceleration data.  Example Code‚Äã  //Arduino code //Code for print request data to serial monitor #include<CoDrone.h> //header void setup(){ //open serial and connect CoDrone.begin(115200); CoDrone.pair(Nearest); } void loop(){ // Struct for get accelerometer data acceldata accel; CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkBroadcast_Active); //link module mode change => Active accel = CoDrone.getAccelerometer(); //save request data delay(100); CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkModeMute); //link module mode change => Mute delay(100); Serial.println(""); Serial.println("--------- Now -----------"); Serial.print("accel x : \t"); Serial.println(accel.x); Serial.print("accel y : \t"); Serial.println(accel.y); Serial.print("accel z : \t"); Serial.println(accel.z); }

searchDocs.title: getAngularSpeed()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This function gets the data from the gyrometer sensor for the roll, pitch, and yaw angular speed.  Syntax‚Äã  getAngularSpeed()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  struct gyrodata: Returns a struct with angular speed data.  Example Code‚Äã  //Arduino code //Code for print request data to serial monitor #include<CoDrone.h> //header void setup(){ //open serial and connect CoDrone.begin(115200); CoDrone.pair(Nearest); } void loop(){ // Struct for get Angular speed(gyro) data gyrodata gyro; CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkBroadcast_Active); //link module mode change => Active gyro = CoDrone.getAngularSpeed(); //save request data delay(100); CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkModeMute); //link module mode change => Mute delay(100); Serial.println(""); Serial.println("--------- Now -----------"); Serial.print("gyro roll : \t"); Serial.println(gyro.roll); Serial.print("gyro pitch : \t"); Serial.println(gyro.pitch); Serial.print("gyro yaw : \t"); Serial.println(gyro.yaw); }

searchDocs.title: getBatteryPercentage()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This function gets the battery percentage of the drone, returning a value from 0 to 100.  Syntax‚Äã  getBatteryPercentage()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  percentage: The battery‚Äôs percentage as an integer from 0 - 100.  Example Code‚Äã  //Arduino code //Code for print request data to serial monitor #include<CoDrone.h> //header void setup(){ //open serial and connect CoDrone.begin(115200); CoDrone.pair(Nearest); } void loop(){ int batteryPercentage; CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkBroadcast_Active); //link module mode change => Active batteryPercentage = CoDrone.getBatteryPercentage(); //save request data delay(100); CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkModeMute); //link module mode change => Mute delay(100); Serial.println(""); Serial.println("--------- Now -----------"); Serial.print("batteryPercentage : \t"); Serial.println(batteryPercentage); }

searchDocs.title: getBatteryVoltage()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This function gets the voltage of the battery  Syntax‚Äã  getBatteryVoltage()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  voltage: The voltage of the battery as an a float  Example Code‚Äã  //Arduino code //Code for print request data to serial monitor #include<CoDrone.h> //header void setup(){ //open serial and connect CoDrone.begin(115200); CoDrone.pair(Nearest); } void loop(){ int batteryVoltage; CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkBroadcast_Active); //link module mode change => Active batteryVoltage = CoDrone.getBatteryVoltage(); //save request data delay(100); CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkModeMute); //link module mode change => Mute delay(100); Serial.println(""); Serial.println("--------- Now -----------"); Serial.print("batteryVoltage : \t"); Serial.println(batteryVoltage); }

searchDocs.title: getDroneTemp()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This is a getter function gets the data from the drone‚Äôs temperature sensor. Importantly, it reads the drone‚Äôs temperature, not the air around it.  Syntax‚Äã  getDroneTemp()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  temperature: The temperature in Celsius as an integer.  Example Code‚Äã  //Arduino code //Code for print request data to serial monitor #include<CoDrone.h> //header void setup(){ //open serial and connect CoDrone.begin(115200); CoDrone.pair(Nearest); } void loop(){ int temperature; CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkBroadcast_Active); //link module mode change => Active temperature = CoDrone.getDroneTemp(); //save request data delay(100); CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkModeMute); //link module mode change => Mute delay(100); Serial.println(""); Serial.println("--------- Now -----------"); Serial.print("temperature : \t"); Serial.println(temperature); }

searchDocs.title: getGyroAngles()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This function gets the data from the gyrometer sensor to determine the roll, pitch, and yaw as angles.  Syntax‚Äã  getGyroAngles()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  struct angledata: Returns a struct with angle data.  Example Code‚Äã  //Arduino code //Code for print request data to serial monitor #include<CoDrone.h> //header void setup(){ //open serial and connect CoDrone.begin(115200); CoDrone.pair(Nearest); } void loop(){ // Struct for get angles(attitude) data angledata angle; CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkBroadcast_Active); //link module mode change => Active angle = CoDrone.getGyroAngles(); //save request data delay(100); CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkModeMute); //link module mode change => Mute delay(100); Serial.println(""); Serial.println("--------- Now -----------"); Serial.print("angle roll : \t"); Serial.println(angle.roll); Serial.print("angle pitch : \t"); Serial.println(angle.pitch); Serial.print("angle yaw : \t"); Serial.println(angle.yaw); }

searchDocs.title: getHeight()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This is a getter function gets the current height of the drone from the object directly below its IR sensor.  Syntax‚Äã  getHeight()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  height: The current height above the object directly below the drone‚Äôs IR height sensor as an int (mm).  Example Code‚Äã  //Arduino code //Code for print request data to serial monitor #include<CoDrone.h> //header void setup(){ //open serial and connect CoDrone.begin(115200); CoDrone.pair(Nearest); } void loop(){ int height; CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkBroadcast_Active); //link module mode change => Active height = CoDrone.getHeight(); //save request data delay(100); CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkModeMute); //link module mode change => Mute delay(100); Serial.println(""); Serial.println("--------- Now -----------"); Serial.print("height : \t"); Serial.println(height); }

searchDocs.title: getOptFlowPosition()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This function gets the x and y coordinates from the optical flow sensor. Keep in mind, the positioning does not take rotation into account.  Syntax‚Äã  getOptFlowPosition()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  struct optdata: Returns a struct with optical flow sensor data  Example Code‚Äã  //Arduino code //Code for print request data to serial monitor #include<CoDrone.h> //header void setup(){ //open serial and connect CoDrone.begin(115200); CoDrone.pair(Nearest); } void loop(){ // Struct for get optical flow sensor data optdata opt; CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkBroadcast_Active); //link module mode change => Active opt = CoDrone.getOptFlowPosition(); //save request data delay(100); CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkModeMute); //link module mode change => Mute delay(100); Serial.println(""); Serial.println("--------- Now -----------"); Serial.print("opt x : \t"); Serial.println(opt.x); Serial.print("opt y : \t"); Serial.println(opt.y); }

searchDocs.title: getPressure()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This is a getter function gets the data from the barometer sensor.  Syntax‚Äã  getPressure()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  pressure: The barometer‚Äôs air pressure in millibars at (0.13 resolution).  Example Code‚Äã  //Arduino code //Code for print request data to serial monitor #include<CoDrone.h> //header void setup(){ //open serial and connect CoDrone.begin(115200); CoDrone.pair(Nearest); } void loop(){ int pressure; CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkBroadcast_Active); //link module mode change => Active pressure = CoDrone.getPressure(); //save request data delay(100); CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkModeMute); //link module mode change => Mute delay(100); Serial.println(""); Serial.println("--------- Now -----------"); Serial.print("pressure : \t"); Serial.println(pressure); }

searchDocs.title: getState()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This function gets the state of the drone, as in whether it‚Äôs: ready, takeoff, flight, flip, stop, landing, reverse, accident, error.  Syntax‚Äã  getState()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  enum state: Returns an enum value (fMode_Ready, fMode_TakeOff, fMode_Flight, fMode_Flip, fMode_Stop, fMode_Landing, fMode_Reverse, fMode_Accident, fMode_Error).  Example Code‚Äã  //Arduino code //Code for print request data to serial monitor #include<CoDrone.h> //header void setup(){ //open serial and connect CoDrone.begin(115200); CoDrone.pair(Nearest); int state; state = CoDrone.getState(); //save request data delay(50); if(state == fMode_Ready) CoDrone.takeoff(); CoDrone.hover(3); CoDrone.land(); } void loop(){ }

searchDocs.title: getTrim()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This function gets the current trim values of the drone.  Syntax‚Äã  getTrim()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  struct trimdata: Returns a struct with trim data  Example Code‚Äã  //Arduino code //Code for print request data to serial monitor #include<CoDrone.h> //header void setup(){ //open serial and connect CoDrone.begin(115200); CoDrone.pair(Nearest); } void loop(){ // Struct for get trim data trimdata trim; CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkBroadcast_Active); //link module mode change => Active trim = CoDrone.getTrim(); //save request data delay(100); CoDrone.Send_LinkModeBroadcast(LinkModeMute); //link module mode change => Mute delay(100); Serial.println(""); Serial.println("--------- Now -----------"); Serial.print("trim roll : \t"); Serial.println(trim.roll); Serial.print("trim pitch : \t"); Serial.println(trim.pitch); Serial.print("trim yaw : \t"); Serial.println(trim.yaw); Serial.print("trim throttle : \t"); Serial.println(trim.throttle); }

searchDocs.title: calibrate_gyro()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Reads from the previous MPU offsets file unless the file does not exist. If an offsets file does not exist, then it will create an offsets file by taking the average of multiple readings from the sensor. While running this function, make sure Zumi is not moving and is resting on a flat surface. This function calls zumi.mpu.calibrate_MPU().  Syntax‚Äã  calibrate_gyro()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward(40,2.0) time.sleep(2) zumi.calibrate_gyro() time.sleep(2) zumi.forward(40,2.0) print("Done")

searchDocs.title: calibrate_MPU()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Reads from the previous MPU offsets file unless the file does not exist. If an offsets file does not exist, then it will create an offsets file by taking the average of multiple readings from the sensor. While running this function, make sure Zumi is not moving and is resting on a flat surface.  Syntax‚Äã  calibrate_MPU() calibrate_MPU(count=100)   Parameters‚Äã  integer count: the number of samples you want Zumi to take. Increase to improve accuracy.  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() #Zumi will take 500 samples/readings zumi.mpu.calibrate_MPU(count=500) #this is the order the offsets will be printed print("angular speed rad/sec Gx,Gy,Gz") print("linear acceleration Ax,Ay,Az") #print the offsets of each Axis zumi.mpu.print_offsets()

searchDocs.title: get_orientation()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Uses the acceleration values to find Zumi's orientation with respect to the strongest force being applied to Zumi (gravity).  Syntax‚Äã  get_orientation()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  integer Orientation state: -1 = unknown 0 = probably falling or moving between states 1 = camera straight up 2 = camera facing down 3 = on right side 4 = on left side 5 = wheels on floor 6 = wheels facing up (upside down) 7 = accelerating faster than 1g   Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() #grab zumi and place it on any side #example: upside down, on its nose etc. for i in range(20): orientation = zumi.get_orientation() print(orientation) time.sleep(0.5) print(" done ")

searchDocs.title: read_x_angle()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Calls update_angles() and returns only the x-angle.  Syntax‚Äã  read_x_angle()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  float x-angle: The current x-angle of the Zumi  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import IPython.display zumi = Zumi() for i in range(100): print(zumi.read_x_angle()) IPython.display.clear_output(wait=True) print("done")

searchDocs.title: reset_drive()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Calls both reset_PID() and reset_gyro().  Syntax‚Äã  reset_drive()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0,50): zumi.forward_step(0,50) print(zumi.angle_list[2],", ", zumi.error_past) zumi.stop() zumi.reset_drive() print(" Now ") print(zumi.angle_list[2],", ", zumi.error_past)

searchDocs.title: reset_gyro()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Resets all values in the angle list to 0. Use for driving straight or turning accurately.  Syntax‚Äã  reset_gyro()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() print("z angle " , zumi.angle_list[2]) zumi.turn_left(90,1.2) print("z angle " , zumi.angle_list[2]) zumi.reset_gyro() print("z angle " , zumi.angle_list[2])

searchDocs.title: reset_PID()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Resets the sum of the gyro error to zero as well as the PID error sum. Use for driving straight or turning accurately. This does not reset the P, I, and D values of the Zumi PID control.  Syntax‚Äã  reset_PID()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0,50): zumi.go_straight(50,0) # print the error of the z angle along with some of the PID accumulators print(zumi.PID_time_past,", ", zumi.error_past,", ", zumi.error_sum," , ", zumi.angle_list[2]) zumi.stop() # this will reset those values zumi.reset_PID() print(" Now ") print(zumi.PID_time_past,", ", zumi.error_past,", ", zumi.error_sum, " , ", zumi.angle_list[2])

searchDocs.title: update_angles()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Reads angular speeds and updates the list of angles: The first 3 are angles produced from the gyroscope readings. X angle, Y angle and Z angle in degrees. The next 2 angles are produced by finding the tilt with respect to gravity. X and Y acceleration angles in degrees. Work well if Zumi's wheels point to the floor The next 2 angles are the complementary filtered angles are produced by combining both gyroscope and accelerometer angles for the x and y axis. The next 3 are the rotation angles which are produced using the accelerometer. rotation along X, Y and Z with respect to gravity. The last one is the tilt state.   Syntax‚Äã  update_angles()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  list angles: The updated list of angles in the following format, [Gyro x,Gyro y,Gyro z,Acc x,Acc y,Comp x,Comp y,Rot_x,Rot_y,Rot_z,tilt_state]  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0,100): angles = zumi.update_angles() z_angle = angles[2] print(z_angle) print(" done ")

searchDocs.title: back_left_detect()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Returns True if the back left IR sensor detects a value below a threshold. The value decreases as the light reflected back to the receiver increases.  Syntax‚Äã  back_left_detect() back_left_detect(threshold=100)  Parameters‚Äã  integer threshold: Threshold value (0 - 255) of the back left IR sensor  Returns‚Äã  boolean detected: Returns True if sensor is triggered.   Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0,100): if zumi.back_left_detect(): print("Detected!") time.sleep(0.1) # Delay for I2C

Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0,100): if zumi.back_right_detect(): print("Detected!") time.sleep(0.1) # Delay for I2C

searchDocs.title: calibrate_gyro()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Reads from the previous MPU offsets file unless the file does not exist. If an offsets file does not exist, then it will create an offsets file by taking the average of multiple readings from the sensor. While running this function, make sure Zumi is not moving and is resting on a flat surface. This function calls zumi.mpu.calibrate_MPU().  Syntax‚Äã  calibrate_gyro()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward(40,2.0) time.sleep(2) zumi.calibrate_gyro() time.sleep(2) zumi.forward(40,2.0) print("Done")

searchDocs.title: calibrate_MPU()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Reads from the previous MPU offsets file unless the file does not exist. If an offsets file does not exist, then it will create an offsets file by taking the average of multiple readings from the sensor. While running this function, make sure Zumi is not moving and is resting on a flat surface.  Syntax‚Äã  calibrate_MPU() calibrate_MPU(count=100)   Parameters‚Äã  integer count: the number of samples you want Zumi to take. Increase to improve accuracy.  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() #Zumi will take 500 samples/readings zumi.mpu.calibrate_MPU(count=500) #this is the order the offsets will be printed print("angular speed rad/sec Gx,Gy,Gz") print("linear acceleration Ax,Ay,Az") #print the offsets of each Axis zumi.mpu.print_offsets()

Syntax‚Äã  front_left_detect() front_left_detect(threshold=100)  Parameters‚Äã  integer threshold: Threshold value (0 - 255) of the front left IR sensor  Returns‚Äã  boolean detected: Returns True if sensor is triggered.   Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0,100): if zumi.front_left_detect(): print("Detected!") time.sleep(0.1) # Delay for I2C

searchDocs.title: get_all_IR_data()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Returns the readings from all 6 IR sensors.  Syntax‚Äã  get_all_IR_data()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  list IR sensor readings: list of all 6 IR sensor values (0 - 255)   IR sensor indices: index 0 - Front right sensor index 1 - Bottom right sensor index 2 - Back right sensor index 3 - Bottom left sensor index 4 - Back left sensor index 5 - Front left sensor   Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0,100): ir_readings = zumi.get_all_IR_data() print(ir_readings) time.sleep(0.1) # Delay for I2C

searchDocs.title: get_battery_voltage()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Get the reading from battery level.  If you are charging Zumi RED LED ON you will see roughly 1.1-1.20 volts.  The battery should reach a max of 4.20 volts and the lowest it should ever reach is 3.0 volts. These values will only show up if the switch is in the on position and the RED led is not visible.  Syntax‚Äã  get_battery_voltage()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  float voltage: The battery's voltage in units of Volts.  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0,10): # battery level is updated every 500ms or half a second time.sleep(0.5) battery = zumi.get_battery_voltage() print(battery)

searchDocs.title: get_IR_data()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Get the reading from the IR sensors and the index specified.  Syntax‚Äã  get_IR_data(ir_sensor_index)   Parameters‚Äã  integer ir_sensor_index: The specified index (0 - 5) from the IR sensors reading list.  IR sensor indices:  0 IR.FRONT_RIGHT = Front right sensor1 IR.BOTTOM_RIGHT = Bottom right sensor2 IR.BACK_RIGHT = Back right sensor3 IR.BOTTOM_LEFT = Bottom left sensor4 IR.BACK_LEFT = Back left sensor5 IR.FRONT_LEFT = Front left sensor  Returns‚Äã  integer IR sensor reading: IR sensor value for the given sensor (0 - 255).  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() FRONT_RIGHT = 0 for i in range(5): zumi.forward(40,1) ir_reading = zumi.get_IR_data(FRONT_RIGHT) print(ir_reading) # Divide by 4 because note is between 0 and 60 time.sleep(0.05)

searchDocs.title: get_orientation_message()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Uses the acceleration values to find Zumi's orientation with respect to the strongest force being applied to Zumi (gravity). This function returns the orientation as a string.  Syntax‚Äã  get_orientation_message()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  string orientation state: a description of the orientation state   Descriptions of rientation state: "unknown" "face up" "face down" "right side down" "left side down" "upright" "upside down" "accelerating"   Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() #grab zumi and place it on any side #example: upside down, on its nose etc. for i in range(20): orientation = zumi.get_orientation_message() print(orientation) time.sleep(0.5) print(" done ")

searchDocs.title: get_orientation()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Uses the acceleration values to find Zumi's orientation with respect to the strongest force being applied to Zumi (gravity).  Syntax‚Äã  get_orientation()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  integer Orientation state: -1 = unknown 0 = probably falling or moving between states 1 = camera straight up 2 = camera facing down 3 = on right side 4 = on left side 5 = wheels on floor 6 = wheels facing up (upside down) 7 = accelerating faster than 1g   Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() #grab zumi and place it on any side #example: upside down, on its nose etc. for i in range(20): orientation = zumi.get_orientation() print(orientation) time.sleep(0.5) print(" done ")

searchDocs.title: reset_drive()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Calls both reset_PID() and reset_gyro(). Use for driving straight or turning accurately.  Syntax‚Äã  reset_drive()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0,50): zumi.forward_step(0,50) print(zumi.angle_list[2],", ", zumi.error_past) zumi.stop() zumi.reset_drive() print(" Now ") print(zumi.angle_list[2],", ", zumi.error_past)

This does not reset the P, I, and D values of the Zumi PID control.  Syntax‚Äã  reset_PID()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0,50): zumi.go_straight(50,0) #print the error of the z angle along with some of the PID accumulators print(zumi.PID_time_past,", ", zumi.error_past,", ", zumi.error_sum," , ", zumi.angle_list[2]) zumi.stop() #this will reset those values zumi.reset_PID() print(" Now ") print(zumi.PID_time_past,", ", zumi.error_past,", ", zumi.error_sum, " , ", zumi.angle_list[2])

searchDocs.title: update_angles()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Reads angular speeds and updates the list of angles: The first 3 are angles produced from the gyroscope readings. X angle, Y angle and Z angle in degrees. The next 2 angles are produced by finding the tilt with respect to gravity. X and Y acceleration angles in degrees. Work well if Zumi's wheels point to the floor The next 2 angles are the complementary filtered angles are produced by combining both gyroscope and accelerometer angles for the x and y axis. The next 3 are the rotation angles which are produced using the accelerometer. rotation along X, Y and Z with respect to gravity. The last one is the tilt state.   Syntax‚Äã  update_angles()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  list angles: The updated list of angles in the following format, [Gyro x,Gyro y,Gyro z,Acc x,Acc y,Comp x,Comp y,Rot_x,Rot_y,Rot_z,tilt_state]  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0,100): angles = zumi.update_angles() z_angle = angles[2] print(z_angle) print(" done ")

searchDocs.title: circle_left()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in a counterclockwise circle.  Syntax‚Äã  circle_left() circle_left(speed=30, step=2)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: The driving speed (0 - 80) integer step: The angle step size (decrease for wider turns, increase for tighter turns)  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward(40,1) zumi.circle_left(step=3)

searchDocs.title: circle_right()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in a clockwise circle.  Syntax‚Äã  circle_right() circle_right(speed=30, step=2)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: The driving speed (0 - 80) integer step: The angle step size (decrease for wider turns, increase for tighter turns)  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward(40,1) zumi.circle_right(step=3)

searchDocs.title: circle()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in a circle (counterclockwise by default).  Syntax‚Äã  circle() circle(speed=30, step=2, direction=1, delay=0.02)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: The driving speed (0 - 80) integer step: The angle step size (decrease for wider turns, increase for tighter turns)integer direction: -1 for clockwise and +1 for counterclockwise float delay: The time delay between each angle step  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward(40,1) zumi.circle(speed=60, step=4, direction=-1)

searchDocs.title: control_motors()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Sets the speed of each individual motor. The changes take place immediately. This function does not include a stop command or any sensor feedback.  Syntax‚Äã  control_motors(right,left)   Parameters‚Äã  integer right: The speed value of the right motor (-126-127). Positive values for forward, negative values for reverse. integer left: The speed value of the left motor (-126-127). Positive values for forward, negative values for reverse.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.control_motors(30,30) time.sleep(2) zumi.stop()

searchDocs.title: drive_over_markers()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Zumi will drive over the specified number of alternating black and white horizontal lines at least 2 centimeters wide. Zumi will stop when the number of markers have been crossed or if the timeout ends, whichever is first. (Avoid making the speed very high, zumi will most likely overshoot since it has a lot of speed)  Syntax‚Äã  zumi.drive_over_markers(5) zumi.drive_over_markers(road_markers=3,speed=10,ir_threshold=120,time_out=3)   Parameters‚Äã  integer road_markers: The number of road markers to drive over integer speed: The speed value (0 - 80) integer ir_threshold: The IR threshold value for the bottom left IR sensors to detect black or white. integer time_out: Number of seconds before the timeout ends and Zumi stops driving.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() #must start off in a black area. zumi.drive_over_markers(5) #Drive over 10 road marker with a timeout of 6 seconds zumi.drive_over_markers(5,40,100,3)

searchDocs.title: figure_8()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in a figure 8.  Syntax‚Äã  figure_8() figure_8(speed=30, step=3, delay=0.02)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: The driving speed (0 - 80) integer step: The angle step size (decrease for wider turns, increase for tighter turns) float delay: The time delay between each angle step   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward(40,1) zumi.figure_8(step=5)

searchDocs.title: forward_avoid_collision()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi forward at a default speed of 40 for 1 second in the direction Zumi is currently facing. If either of the front IR sensor values go below the threshold, Zumi will stop even if the duration or timeout is not complete.  Syntax‚Äã  forward_avoid_collision(speed=40, duration=1.0) forward_avoid_collision(speed=40, duration=1.0, desired_angle=None, left_th=150, right_th=150)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: The driving speed value (0 - 80) float duration: Number of seconds Zumi will drive and check for collision integer desired_angle: Heading or desired angle, in degrees (Default to None which is Zumi's current heading) integer left_th: threshold of the front left IR sensor (0 - 255) integer right_th: threshold of the front right IR sensor (0 - 255)   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward_avoid_collision(40,2)

searchDocs.title: forward_step()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Takes one drive "step" to correct for the set heading. This function only works when called inside of a loop.  Syntax‚Äã  forward_step(speed, desired_angle) forward_step(speed, desired_angle, max_speed=127)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: The drive speed value (0 - 127); must be below the max_speed integer desired_angle: heading (0 degrees is defined when the Zumi object is created.) integer max_speed: Caps the max speed. Default to 127.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0, 200): zumi.forward_step(40,20) zumi.stop()

searchDocs.title: forward()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi forward at a default speed of 40 for 1 second in the direction Zumi is currently facing.  Syntax‚Äã  forward() forward(speed=40, duration=1.0, desired_angle=None)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: The driving speed value (0 - 80) float duration: Number of seconds Zumi will drive forward integer desired_angle: Heading or desired angle, in degrees, to drive in (When None is selected Zumi drives wherever she is facing)  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward() time.sleep(1) zumi.forward(speed=50) time.sleep(1) zumi.forward(duration=2.1) time.sleep(1)

searchDocs.title: funnel_align()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Zumi will try to align to the funnel piece on the competition field (Click here for a PDF version).  Syntax‚Äã  funnel_align(speed=20, duration=1.0) funnel_align(speed=20, duration=1, angle=None, angle_adj=2, l_th=100, r_th=100)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: The driving speed value (0 - 80) float duration: Number of seconds Zumi will try to align to the funnel piece integer angle: Heading or desired angle, in degrees, (Default to None which is Zumi's current heading) integer angle_adj: The angle, in degrees, Zumi will turn if one IR sensor detects white integer l_th: threshold of the bottom left IR sensor (0 - 255) integer r_th: threshold of the bottom right IR sensor (0 - 255)   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() zumi.funnel_align(speed=10,duration=3,angle_adj=1.1)

searchDocs.title: go_reverse()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Takes one drive "step" in reverse to correct for the set heading. This function only works when called inside of a loop.  Syntax‚Äã  go_reverse(speed, desired_angle) go_reverse(speed, desired_angle, max_speed=127)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: Drive speed (0 - 127); must be below the max_speed integer desired_angle: heading (0 degrees is defined when the Zumi object is created.) integer max_speed: Caps the max speed. Default to 127.  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0, 200): zumi.go_reverse(40,0) zumi.stop()

searchDocs.title: go_straight()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Takes one drive "step" to correct for the set heading. This function only works when called inside of a loop.  Syntax‚Äã  go_straight(speed, desired_angle) go_straight(speed, desired_angle, max_speed=127)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: Drive speed (0 - 127); must be below the max_speed integer desired_angle: heading (0 degrees is defined when the Zumi object is created.) integer max_speed: Caps the max speed. Default to 127.  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() for i in range(0, 200): zumi.go_straight(40,0) zumi.stop()

searchDocs.title: j_turn()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in a j-turn.  Syntax‚Äã  j_turn() j_turn(speed=80, step=4, delay=0.005)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: The forward speed (0 - 80) integer step: The angle step size (decrease for wider turns, increase for tighter turns) float delay: The time delay between each angle step  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward(40,1) zumi.j_turn(speed=60, delay=0.003)

searchDocs.title: left_u_turn()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in a left u-turn.  Syntax‚Äã  left_u_turn() left_u_turn(speed=30, step=4, delay=0.02)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: The forward speed (0 - 80) integer step: The angle step size (decrease for wider turns, increase for tighter turns) float delay: The time delay between each angle step  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward(40,1) zumi.left_u_turn() time.sleep(1) zumi.left_u_turn(step=3)

searchDocs.title: line_follower()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  On the road, Zumi uses the camera to detect lanes and stay inside of them.  Syntax‚Äã  zumi.line_follower(duration=3, left_thresh=100,right_thresh=100)  Parameters‚Äã  integer duration: Number of seconds Zumi will drive on the line integer left_thresh: threshold of the bottom left IR sensor. By default, threshold is 100 integer right_thresh: threshold of the bottom right IR sensor. By default, threshold is 100   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() zumi.line_follower(3) zumi.line_follower(3, left_thresh=100,right_thresh=100)

searchDocs.title: line_follow_gyro_assist()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi forward at a default speed of 20 for 1 second in the direction Zumi is currently facing. Zumi will stop when the duration or timeout is over. If the bottom IR sensors detect a black line, Zumi will continue to drive. If one or the other sensor detects white, Zumi will auto-adjust to stay on the line. If both sensors detect white, Zumi will stop even if the duration has not been met.  Syntax‚Äã  line_follow_gyro_assist(speed=20, duration=1.0) line_follow_gyro_assist(speed=20, duration=1, angle=None, angle_adj=2, l_th=100, r_th=100)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: The drive speed value (0 - 80) integer duration: Number of seconds Zumi will drive on the line integer angle: Heading or desired angle, in degrees (default is None which is Zumi's current heading) integer angle_adj: The number of degrees Zumi will turn if one IR sensor detects white. integer l_th: threshold of the bottom left IR sensor. integer r_th: threshold of the bottom right IR sensor.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() zumi.line_follow_gyro_assist(speed=10,duration=3,angle_adj=1.1)

searchDocs.title: move_centimeters()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This method uses a best fit linear approximation of the distance traveled over time. It uses the equation y = mx + b, where:  y is the distance traveledm is the predicted speed in centimeters per secondx is the time elapsedb is the slope intercept  If the PID values are not set the internal default values will be set.  If the angle is not input Zumi will drive to whatever angle it is currently facing.  Syntax‚Äã  move_centimeters(distance, angle) move_centimeters(distance, angle=None, k_p=None, k_i=None, k_d=None)   Parameters‚Äã  float distance: the distance in centimeters you want to travel integer angle: heading, in degrees (0 degrees is defined when the Zumi object is created.) Default to None float k_p: P-gain. Default to None. float k_i: I-gain. Default to None. float k_d: D-gain. Default to None.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() zumi.move_centimeters(10) zumi.move_centimeters(10,90) zumi.move_centimeters(15,0)

searchDocs.title: move_inches()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This method uses a best fit linear approximation of the distance traveled over time. It uses the equation y = mx + b, where:  y is the distance traveledm is the predicted speed in inches per secondx is the time elapsedb is the slope intercept  If the PID values are not set the internal default values will be set.  If the angle is not input Zumi will drive to whatever angle it is currently facing.  Syntax‚Äã  move_inches(distance, angle) move_inches(distance, angle=None, k_p=None, k_i=None, k_d=None)   Parameters‚Äã  float distance: the distance in inches you want to travel integer angle: heading, in degrees (0 degrees is defined when the Zumi object is created.) Default to None float k_p: P-gain. Default to None. float k_i: I-gain. Default to None. float k_d: D-gain. Default to None.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() zumi.move_inches(5) zumi.move_inches(6,90) zumi.move_inches(5,0)

searchDocs.title: move_to_coordinate()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  This method drives Zumi from an origin to an x,y position in inches. Using this function will keep track of Zumi's coordinates. To reset the origin, use the reset_coordinate() function. This method uses a best fit linear approximation of the distance traveled over time. It uses the equation y = mx + b, where:  y is the distance traveledm is the predicted speed in inches per secondx is the time elapsedb is the slope intercept  Syntax‚Äã  move_to_coordinate(desired_x, desired_y) move_to_coordinate(desired_x, desired_y, k_p=None, k_i=None, k_d=None, units="in"):   Parameters‚Äã  float desired_x: The x-coordinate of the destination float desired_y: The y-coordinate of the destination float k_p: P-gain. Default to None. float k_i: I-gain. Default to None. float k_d: D-gain. Default to None. string units: Defaults to "in" or inches. Set it to "cm" for centimeters.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code Sample 1‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() # a square zumi.move_to_coordinate(6,0) zumi.move_to_coordinate(6,6) zumi.move_to_coordinate(0,6) zumi.move_to_coordinate(0,0)   Sample 2  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() # Avoid this zumi.move_to_coordinate(10,0) time.sleep(1) # zumi wont drive the second time since its already at (10, 0) zumi.move_to_coordinate(10,0)   Sample 3  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() # Avoid this zumi.move_to_coordinate(10,0) time.sleep(1) zumi.reset_coordinate() # zumi will drive the second time since its position will be reset, and will move a total of 20 inches from the start zumi.move_to_coordinate(10,0)

searchDocs.title: parallel_park()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in a parallel park maneuver.  Syntax‚Äã  parallel_park() parallel_park(speed=15, step=1, delay=0.01)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: Drive speed (0 - 80) integer step: The angle step size (decrease for wider turns, increase for tighter turns) float delay: The time delay between each angle step   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward(40,2) zumi.parallel_park(speed=20, step=2)

searchDocs.title: rectangle_left()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in a counterclockwise rectangle.  Syntax‚Äã  rectangle_left() rectangle_left(speed=40, seconds=1.0, ratio=2)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: Drive speed between (0 - 80) float seconds: Duration in seconds for shorter side float ratio: Ratio of longer side to shorter side (Multiply ratio by seconds to get the duration of the longer side)   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward(40,1) zumi.rectangle_left(ratio=3)

searchDocs.title: rectangle_right()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in a clockwise rectangle.  Syntax‚Äã  rectangle_right() rectangle_right(speed=40, seconds=1.0, ratio=2)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: Drive speed between (0 - 80) float seconds: Duration in seconds for shorter side float ratio: Ratio of longer side to shorter side (Multiply ratio by seconds to get the duration of the longer side)   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward(40,1) zumi.rectangle_right(ratio=3)

searchDocs.title: rectangle()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in a rectangle.  Syntax‚Äã  rectangle() rectangle(speed=40, seconds=1.0, direction=1, ratio=2)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: Drive speed between (0 - 80) float seconds: Duration in seconds for shorter side integer direction: direction of turn (1 for counterclockwise and -1 for clockwise) float ratio: Ratio of longer side to shorter side (Multiply ratio by seconds to get the duration of the longer side)   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.forward(40,1) zumi.rectangle(ratio=3)

searchDocs.title: reset_coordinate()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Will reset the coordinate to (0,0).  Syntax‚Äã  reset_coordinate()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() zumi.move_to_coordinate(10,0) zumi.reset_coordinate() #zumi will drive another 10 inches zumi.move_to_coordinate(10,0)

searchDocs.title: reverse_avoid_collision()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in reverse at a default speed of 40 for 1 second in the direction Zumi is currently facing. If either of the back IR sensor values go below the threshold, Zumi will stop even if the duration or timeout is not complete.  Syntax‚Äã  reverse_avoid_collision(speed=40, duration=1.0) reverse_avoid_collision(speed=40, duration=1.0, desired_angle=None, left_th=150, right_th=150)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: Driving speed (0 - 80) float duration: Number of seconds Zumi will drive and check for collision integer desired_angle: Heading or desired angle, in degrees (Default to None which is Zumi's current heading) integer left_th: threshold of the back left IR sensor integer right_th: threshold of the back right IR sensor   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() zumi.reverse_avoid_collision(40,2)

searchDocs.title: reverse_step()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Takes one drive "step" in reverse to correct for the set heading. This function only works when called inside of a loop.  Syntax‚Äã  reverse_step(speed, desired_angle) reverse_step(speed, desired_angle, max_speed=127)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: Drive speed between (0 - 127); must be below the max_speed integer desired_angle: heading, in degrees (0 degrees is defined when the Zumi object is created.) integer max_speed: Caps the max speed. Default to 127.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() for i in range(50): zumi.reverse_step(40,0) zumi.stop()

searchDocs.title: reverse()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in reverse at a default speed of 40 for 1 second in the direction Zumi is currently facing.  Syntax‚Äã  reverse() reverse(speed=40, duration=1.0, desired_angle=None)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: Driving speed between (0 - 80) float duration: Number of seconds Zumi will drive reverse integer desired_angle: Heading or desired angle to drive in, in degrees (When None is selected Zumi drives wherever she is facing)  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.reverse() time.sleep(1) zumi.reverse(speed=50) time.sleep(1) zumi.reverse(duration=2.1) time.sleep(1) zumi.reverse(50,2.1,45)

searchDocs.title: right_u_turn()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in a right u-turn.  Syntax‚Äã  right_u_turn() right_u_turn(speed=30, step=4, delay=0.02)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: Driving speed value (0 - 80) integer step: The angle step size (decrease for wider turns, increase for tighter turns) float delay: The time delay between each angle step.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.right_u_turn(speed=20) time.sleep(1) zumi.right_u_turn(delay=0.04)

searchDocs.title: smooth_forward()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Causes Zumi to gradually accelerate forward to max speed during a given duration before decelerating back to zero.  Syntax‚Äã  smooth_forward(duration) smooth_forward(duration, rate=1)   Parameters‚Äã  float duration: Total duration of drive command including acceleration and deceleration float rate: rate at which speed changes. Default to 1   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.smooth_forward(3) time.sleep(1) zumi.smooth_forward(duration=3,rate=2)

searchDocs.title: smooth_reverse()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Causes Zumi to gradually accelerate in reverse to max speed during a given duration before decelerating back to zero.  Syntax‚Äã  smooth_reverse(duration) smooth_reverse(duration, rate=1)   Parameters‚Äã  float duration: Total duration of drive command including acceleration and deceleration float rate: Rate at which speed changes. Default to 1   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.smooth_reverse(3) time.sleep(1) zumi.smooth_reverse(duration=3,rate=2)

searchDocs.title: smooth_turn_left()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Turns left gradually to reach the desired angle while also going forward. Default to 90 degrees.  Syntax‚Äã  smooth_turn_left() smooth_turn_left(desired_angle=90,speed=20,step=2)   Parameters‚Äã  integer desired_angle: Degrees you want to turn from your starting position integer speed: Driving speed (0 - 80). Default to 20. integer step: The angle step size (decrease for wider turns, increase for tighter turns)   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.smooth_turn_left() time.sleep(1) zumi.smooth_turn_left(speed=30)

searchDocs.title: smooth_turn_right()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Turns right gradually to reach the desired angle while also going forward. Default to 90 degrees.  Syntax‚Äã  smooth_turn_right() smooth_turn_right(desired_angle=90,speed=20,step=2)   Parameters‚Äã  integer desired_angle: Degrees you want to turn from your starting position integer speed: Driving speed between 0 and 80. Default to 20. integer step: The angle step size (decrease for wider turns, increase for tighter turns)   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.smooth_turn_right() time.sleep(1) zumi.smooth_turn_right(speed=30)

searchDocs.title: speed_calibration()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  In order to use this method you will need a speed calibration sheet (Click here for a PDF version). Zumi will drive over 5 horizontal white lines that are 2 centimeters wide. The slope and y_intercept will be generated for the best fit line of the speed prediction. These values will be saved to the Zumi as a text file.  This function is necessary for move_to_coordinate(), move_inches(), and move_centimeters().  Syntax‚Äã  speed_calibration() speed_calibration(speed=40, ir_threshold=100, time_out=3, cm_per_brick=2, show_graphs=False)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: Driving speed value (0 - 80). The lower the more accurate the speed prediction. integer ir_threshold: Integer value for the bottom left IR threshold (0-255). float time_out: The number of seconds before the timeout. float cm_per_brick: The width of each road marker in centimeters. boolean show_graphs: Defaults to False. If set to True, a graph will be displayed with the best fit line prediction. *Note: You may need to run this function twice to see the graph.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi zumi = Zumi() # Place Zumi on the black portion of the speed calibration sheet zumi.speed_calibration() # To show the graphs, replace the original "zumi.speed_calibration" with the following line # zumi.speed_calibration(show_graphs = True)

searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Drives Zumi in a triangle. Default is counterclockwise.  Syntax‚Äã  triangle() triangle(speed=40, seconds=1.5, direction=1)   Parameters‚Äã  integer speed: Drive speed value (0 - 80) float seconds: Duration in seconds Zumi drives for each side integer direction: Direction of turn (-1 for clockwise and +1 for counterclockwise)  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.triangle(speed=30, direction=-1)

searchDocs.title: turn_left()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Causes Zumi to turn left the specified number of degrees. Default to 90 degrees.  Syntax‚Äã  turn_left() turn_left(desired_angle=90, duration=1.0)   Parameters‚Äã  integer desired_angle: Degrees you want to turn to the left from your starting position. Default to 90. Only positive values. float duration: The amount of time in seconds Zumi will try and complete the turn. Increase for turns greater than 90 degrees.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.turn_left() time.sleep(1) zumi.turn_left(130,1.5)

searchDocs.title: turn_right()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Causes Zumi to turn right the specified number of degrees. Default to 90 degrees.  Syntax‚Äã  turn_right() turn_right(desired_angle=90,duration=1.0)   Parameters‚Äã  integer desired_angle: Degrees you want to turn to the right from your starting position. Default to 90. Only positive values. float duration: The amount of time in seconds Zumi will try and complete the turn. Increase for turns greater than 90 degrees.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.turn_right(45) time.sleep(1) zumi.turn_right(200,duration=1.3)

searchDocs.title: turn()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Zumi will turn to a desired angle.  Syntax‚Äã  turn(desired_angle) turn(desired_angle, duration=1.5, max_speed=25, accuracy=1):   Parameters‚Äã  integer desired_angle: Angle to turn. Positive degrees to the left. Negative degrees to the right. float duration: Number of seconds Zumi will perform the command. integer speed: The max motor speed for turning (0 - 80). integer accuracy: The tolerance of +- degrees (e.g. accuracy = 1 means +1 or -1 degree off from desired_angle).   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi import time zumi = Zumi() # zumi will turn to the left zumi.turn(90) #zumi will turn to the right 90 degrees from the starting angle zumi.turn(-90)

searchDocs.title: play_note()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Play a note, from C2 - B6.  Syntax‚Äã  play_note(note_type) play_note(note_type, note_duration=500)   Parameters‚Äã  integer/enum note_type: Integer from 0 to 60 or enum from Note class. Setting the note to 0 will result in no sound. integer note_duration: Default to 500 milliseconds but can be an integer from 0 to 2500 milliseconds. Must be in 100 millisecond increments ex. 100, 200, 500, 2000. If 0 note will play forever.   class Note: C2 = 1 CS2 = 2 D2 = 3 DS2 = 4 E2 = 5 F2 = 6 FS2 = 7 G2 = 8 GS2 = 9 A2 = 10 AS2 = 11 B2 = 12 C3 = 13 CS3 = 14 D3 = 15 DS3 = 16 E3 = 17 F3 = 18 FS3 = 19 G3 = 20 GS3 = 21 A3 = 22 AS3 = 23 B3 = 24 C4 = 25 CS4 = 26 D4 = 27 DS4 = 28 E4 = 29 F4 = 30 FS4 = 31 G4 = 32 GS4 = 33 A4 = 34 AS4 = 35 B4 = 36 C5 = 37 CS5 = 38 D5 = 39 DS5 = 40 E5 = 41 F5 = 42 FS5 = 43 G5 = 44 GS5 = 45 A5 = 46 AS5 = 47 B5 = 48 C6 = 49 CS6 = 50 D6 = 51 DS6 = 52 E6 = 53 F6 = 54 FS6 = 55 G6 = 56 GS6 = 57 A6 = 58 AS6 = 59 B6 = 60   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi from zumi.protocol import Note import time zumi = Zumi() zumi.play_note(30, 500) time.sleep(1) zumi.play_note(Note.C4) time.sleep(1) # will stop the buzzer zumi.play_note(0, 0)

searchDocs.title: capture()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Takes a picture using the PiCamera and saves it in an array. searchDocs.title: clear_output()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Clear the output for the next image to show.  Syntax‚Äã  clear_output()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  from zumi.util.camera import Camera camera = Camera() camera.start_camera() try: for x in range(30): frame = camera.capture() camera.show_image(frame) camera.clear_output() # Clear the output for the next image to show finally: camera.close()

searchDocs.title: close()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Releases camera's resources  Syntax‚Äã  close()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.util.camera import Camera camera=Camera() camera.start_camera() camera.save_photo() camera.close() # closes camera stream

searchDocs.title: is_closed()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Checks if the camera stream is open  Syntax‚Äã  is_closed()  Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  Boolean: Returns True if camera stream is open. Otherwise returns False  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.util.camera import Camera camera=Camera() camera.start_camera() camera.close() print("Camera is closed?") print(camera.is_closed()) if not camera.is_closed(): camera.close()

searchDocs.title: save_photo()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Captures an image and saves it in the working directory.  Syntax‚Äã  save_photo() save_photo(file_name)  Parameters‚Äã  string file_name: The name of the image file that will be saved. Default name (no input) is the current time.  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.util.camera import Camera camera=Camera() camera.start_camera() camera.save_photo() #"<current_time>.jpg" file will be saved in the current working directory camera.save_photo("Cheese") #"Cheese.jpg" file will be saved in the current working directory camera.close()

searchDocs.title: show_image()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Displays an image taken from Zumi's camera.  Syntax‚Äã  show_image(frame)   Parameters‚Äã  ndarray frame: An image array that will be displayed  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.util.camera import Camera import time camera=Camera() camera.start_camera() frame = camera.capture() camera.show_image(frame) camera.close()

searchDocs.title: start_camera()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Turns on the camera  Syntax‚Äã  start_camera()   Parameters‚Äã  None  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.util.camera import Camera import cv2 import IPython.display import PIL.Image from io import BytesIO import time # you can change the resolution of the camera # using the image_w = image width # and the image_h = image heigth #camera = Camera(image_w=1280,image_h=960) #camera = Camera(image_w=1024,image_h=768) #camera = Camera(image_w=128,image_h=64) camera = Camera(image_w=60,image_h=32) camera.start_camera() # opens camera stream time_start = time.time() try: for i in range(30): frame = camera.capture() img = PIL.Image.fromarray(frame, "RGB") buffer = BytesIO() img.save(buffer,format="JPEG") IPython.display.display(IPython.display.Image(data=buffer.getvalue())) IPython.display.clear_output(wait=True) finally: print(30/(time.time()-time_start))

searchDocs.title: fit()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Fits values for prediction. By default, HSV is fitted.  Syntax‚Äã  fit(values)   Parameters‚Äã  string values: values to be fitted for prediction. By default hsv is fitted.  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi from zumi.util.camera import Camera from zumi.util.screen import Screen from zumi.util.color_classifier import ColorClassifier import time camera = Camera() screen = Screen() zumi = Zumi() user_name = 'username' # Type your actual username here project_name = 'project_name' # Type your actual project name here knn = ColorClassifier(user_name=user_name) # Must include "user_name=" train = knn.load_model(project_name) knn.fit("hsv") # Fitting to HSV camera.start_camera() while True: user_input = input("Press 'enter' to predict or 'q to quit: ") if user_input == "q": break image = camera.capture() predict = knn.predict(image) screen.draw_text_center(predict) camera.close()

searchDocs.title: predict()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Predicts a color captured from the Zumi camera.  Syntax‚Äã  predict(pred_features)   Parameters‚Äã  ndarray p*red_features: The image to draw the prediction from  Returns‚Äã  string prediction: The prediction made by the knn color classifier  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi from zumi.util.camera import Camera from zumi.util.screen import Screen from zumi.util.color_classifier import ColorClassifier import time camera = Camera() screen = Screen() zumi = Zumi() user_name = 'username' # Type your actual username here project_name = 'project_name' # Type your actual project name here knn = ColorClassifier(user_name=user_name) # Must include "user_name=" train = knn.load_model(project_name) knn.fit("hsv") # Fitting to HSV camera.start_camera() while True: user_input = input("Press 'enter' to predict or 'q to quit: ") if user_input == "q": break image = camera.capture() predict = knn.predict(image) # Based on the image taken, the knn color classifier will predict a color screen.draw_text_center(predict) # This prediction gets written to the Zumi screen camera.close()

searchDocs.title: load_model()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Loads the model based on your project name.  Syntax‚Äã  load_model(name)   Parameters‚Äã  string name: The project name. This will depend on what you chose to name your project  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.zumi import Zumi from zumi.util.camera import Camera from zumi.util.screen import Screen from zumi.util.color_classifier import ColorClassifier import time camera = Camera() screen = Screen() zumi = Zumi() user_name = 'username' # Type your actual username here project_name = 'project_name' # Type your actual project name here knn = ColorClassifier(user_name=user_name) # Must include "user_name=" train = knn.load_model(project_name) # Loads the model based on your project name. knn.fit("hsv") camera.start_camera() while True: user_input = input("Press 'enter' to predict or 'q to quit: ") if user_input == "q": break image = camera.capture() predict = knn.predict(image) screen.draw_text_center(predict) camera.close()

searchDocs.title: convert_to_gray()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Converts captured image into a grayscaled image.  Syntax‚Äã  convert_to_gray(img)  Parameters‚Äã  ndarray img: an image array to be converted  Returns‚Äã  ndarray image array: a modified image array of img for grayscaling  Example Code‚Äã  from zumi.util.vision import Vision from zumi.util.camera import Camera camera = Camera() vision = Vision() camera.start_camera() img = camera.capture() camera.close() gray = vision.convert_to_gray(img) # Convert it to grayscaled version of img camera.show_image(gray)

searchDocs.title: convert_to_hsv()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Converts captured image to an HSV image.  Syntax‚Äã  convert_to_hsv(img)  Parameters‚Äã  ndarray img: An image array to be converted  Returns‚Äã  ndarray image array: A modified image array of img in the HSV colorspace  Example Code‚Äã  from zumi.util.vision import Vision from zumi.util.camera import Camera camera = Camera() vision = Vision() camera.start_camera() img = camera.capture() camera.close() hsv = vision.convert_to_hsv(img) # Convert it to HSV, hue saturation and value camera.show_image(hsv)

searchDocs.title: get_QR_message()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Returns the message from decoded QR code.  Syntax‚Äã  get_QR_message(Qr_object)  Parameters‚Äã  Decoded Qr_object: decoded QR data (an object of class Decoded) that find_QR_code()  Returns‚Äã  string message: decoded message from QR code  Example Code‚Äã  from zumi.util.vision import Vision from zumi.util.camera import Camera camera = Camera() camera.start_camera() frame = camera.capture() camera.close() qr_code = vision.find_QR_code(frame) message = vision.get_QR_message(qr_code) # returns None if QR code was not detected print(message)

searchDocs.title: find_face()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Searches captured image for facial features to find face's pixel location in the image.  Syntax‚Äã  find_face(frame, scale_factor=1.05, min_neighbors=8, min_size=(40,40))  Parameters‚Äã  ndarray frame: an image array float scale_factor: a number to reduce image size for easier training. By default, scale_factor is 1.05 (reducing the image by 5%) integer min_neighbors: minimum number of neighbors (features that have similarities) integer min_size: minimum size of face to be detected   Returns‚Äã  list area: [x,y,w,h] of the face's x and y coordinates along with the area's width and height. Returns None if not detected  Example Code‚Äã  from zumi.util.camera import Camera from zumi.util.vision import Vision camera = Camera() vision = Vision() camera.start_camera() image = camera.capture() camera.close() face_location = vision.find_face(image, scale_factor = 1.05, min_neighbors=8, min_size= (40,40)) # returns location of face frame within image. None if not found print("[x,y,w,h] =",face_location) camera.show_image(image) # displays image with outlined face (if it exists) in Jupyter Notebook

searchDocs.title: find_stop_sign()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Searches an image for a stop sign and returns a list containing x-y coordinates, width, and height of the stop sign's frame.  Syntax‚Äã  find_stop_sign(frame, scale_factor=1.05, min_neighbors=8, min_size=(40,40))  Parameters‚Äã  ndarray frame: an image array float scale_factor: a number to reduce image size for easier training. By default, scale_factor is 1.05 (reducing the image by 5%) integer min_neighbors: minimum number of neighbors (features that have similarities) integer min_size: minimum size for the stop sign to be detected   Returns‚Äã  list area: [x,y,w,h] of the stop sign's x and y coordinates along with the area's width and height. Returns None if not detected  Example‚Äã  from zumi.util.camera import Camera from zumi.util.vision import Vision camera = Camera() vision = Vision() camera.start_camera() image = camera.capture() camera.close() stop_sign_location = vision.find_stop_sign(image, scale_factor = 1.05, min_neighbors=8, min_size= (40,40)) # returns location of stop sign frame within image. None if not found print("[x,y,w,h] =",stop_sign_location) camera.show_image(image) # displays image with outlined stop sign (if it exists) in Jupyter Notebook

searchDocs.title: find_QR_code()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Processes the image that is given as a parameter and draws a rectangle around the QR code with the decoded message on it.  Syntax‚Äã  find_QR_code(frame)  Parameters‚Äã  *ndarray frame: a NumPy array representing a captured image (image array)  Returns‚Äã  Decoded decoded_Qr: decoded QR data (an object of Decoded class). Returns None if QR code is not detected  Example Code‚Äã  from zumi.zumi import Zumi from zumi.util.camera import Camera from zumi.util.vision import Vision camera = Camera() vision = Vision() camera.start_camera() try: for i in range(50): frame = camera.capture() vision.find_QR_code(frame) camera.show_image(frame) camera.clear_output() finally: print("Done!") camera.close()

searchDocs.title: find_smile()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Searches captured image for smiling facial features to find smile's pixel location in the image.  Syntax‚Äã  find_smile(frame, scale_factor=1.05, min_neighbors=8, min_size=(40,40))  Parameters‚Äã  ndarray frame: a NumPy array representing a captured image (image array) float scale_factor: a number to reduce image size for easier training. By default, scale_factor is 1.05 (reducing the image by 5%) integer min_neighbors: minimum number of neighbors (features that have similarities) integer min_size: minimum size of face to be detected integer max_size: maximum size of face to be detected   Returns‚Äã  list area: [x,y,w,h] of the smiles's x and y coordinates along with the area's width and height. Returns None if not detected  Example Code‚Äã  from zumi.util.camera import Camera from zumi.util.vision import Vision camera = Camera() vision = Vision() camera.start_camera() image = camera.capture() camera.close() smile_location = vision.find_smile(image, scale_factor = 1.05, min_neighbors=8, min_size= (40,40)) # returns location of smile frame within image. None if not found print("[x,y,w,h] =",smile_location) camera.show_image(image) # displays image with outlined smile (if it exists) in Jupyter Notebook

searchDocs.title: draw_arc()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Draws an arc within the boundaries of points x1,y1, and x2,y2 at the specified starting and ending angles.  Syntax‚Äã  draw_arc(x1, y1, x2, y2, start_ang, end_ang) draw_arc(x1, y1, x2, y2, start_ang, end_ang,fill_in=True)   Parameters‚Äã  integer x1: x coordinate of top-left corner for the rectangle enclosing the arc integer y1: y coordinate of top-left corner for the rectangle enclosing the arc integer x2: x coordinate of bottom-right corner for the rectangle enclosing the arc integer y2: y coordinate of bottom-right corner for the rectangle enclosing the arc integer start_ang: starting arc angle, in degrees integer end_ang: ending arc angle, in degrees boolean fill_in: Boolean that selects if the triangle will be filled in (white). Default to True.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.util.screen import Screen screen=Screen() screen.draw_arc(0,0,50,50,-180,0)

Syntax‚Äã  draw_chord(x1, y1, x2, y2, start_ang, end_ang) draw_chord(x1, y1, x2, y2, start_ang, end_ang,fill_in=True)   Parameters‚Äã  integer x1: x coordinate of top-left corner for the rectangle enclosing the chord integer y1: y coordinate of top-left corner for the rectangle enclosing the chord integer x2: x coordinate of bottom-right corner for the rectangle enclosing the chord integer y2: y coordinate of bottom-right corner for the rectangle enclosing the chord integer start_ang: starting angle integer end_ang: ending angle boolean fill_in: Boolean that selects if the triangle will be filled in (white). Default to True.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.util.screen import Screen screen=Screen() screen.draw_chord(0,0,20,20,-180,0) screen.draw_chord(30,30,50,50,-180,0) #do a 360 from -180 degrees to 180 degrees screen.draw_chord(60,30,100,50,-180,180)

searchDocs.title: draw_text()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Draws text to the upper lefthand corner of the screen  Syntax‚Äã  draw_text(string) draw_text(string, x, y, font_size) (display, clear)..  Parameters‚Äã  string string: The text that Zumi will show on the screen integer x: The x coordinate start value of the string, defaults to 1 integer y: The y coordinate start value of the string, defaults to 1 integer font_size: The font size of the string, defaults to 16 pixels  Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.util.screen import Screen import time screen=Screen() for i in range(10): screen.draw_text(str(i)+'!') time.sleep(0.1) screen.clear_display()

searchDocs.title: draw_triangle()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Draws a triangle with 3 points (x1,y1), (x2,y2), (x3,y3): x1, y1, x2, y2, x3, y3.  Syntax‚Äã   draw_triangle(x1,y1,x2,y2,x3,y3) draw_triangle(x1,y1,x2,y2,x3,y3,fill_in=True):   Parameters‚Äã  integer x1: the x coordinate of point 1 integer y1: the y coordinate of point 1 integer x2: the x coordinate of point 2 integer y2: the y coordinate of point 2 integer x3: the x coordinate of point 3 integer y3: the y coordinate of point 3 boolean fill_in: Boolean that selects if the triangle will be filled in (white). Default to True.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.util.screen import Screen screen=Screen() screen.draw_triangle(0,10,20,50,50,0)

searchDocs.title: print()‚Äã
searchDocs.content: Description‚Äã  Prints any number of strings on the screen.  Syntax‚Äã  print(*messages) print(*messages,x=0, y=0, fill_in=True,font_size=12)   Parameters‚Äã  string messages: Any number of strings that will print to the screen integer x: x coordinate of the string. Default to 0. integer y: y coordinate of the string. Default to 0. boolean fill_in: Boolean that selects if text will be white(True) or black (False). Default to True. integer font_size: Pixel size of the font. Default to 12.   Returns‚Äã  None  Example Code‚Äã  #Python code from zumi.util.screen import Screen import time screen=Screen() screen.print("12345678") screen.print("hello", y=15) screen.print("\n\n","Zumi") time.sleep(1) screen.clear_drawing() screen.print("ZUMI",font_size=20)
